I am a graphics and physics focused engineer with a strong interest in real-time
rendering, simulation, and engine architecture. My work centers around building
dynamic rendering systems from first principles -- implementing math libraries, memory management techniques, and GPU pipelines in modern APIs like Vulkan and OpenGL -- as well as physically accurate rendering with techniques like Fresnel and Fourier shaders.

I approach software the same way I approach physics: a deterministic set of
constraints and invariants that must maintain internal consistency. This perspective
influences how I design rendering pipelines, memory management, cross-device
synchronization, and simulation code.

I am currently working on a Vulkan based rendering engine focusing on:

Modern Vulkan features (Dynamic Rendering, VMA, Synch2, Boundless Descriptors)

Cross-platform compatibility

Modularity and top-level configurability

GPU-driven architecture 

VRENDER GitHub

My goal is to work on rendering engines, graphics drivers, or real-time GPU driven
simulations where performance, correctness, and architecture matter.

Below is a short demo highlighting recent rendering and engine work. The footage
demonstrates custom engine systems including geometry streaming, transient mesh
support, and a conformance test driven math abstractions.

Relevant coursework includes computer graphics, real-time environments, engine development, systems programming, data structures,
rigid body mechanics, waves and quantum systems, linear algebra, and differential equations.

I believe string software behaves like a well defined physical system: deterministic, internally consistent, and governed by
invariants.

In Rendering and Simulation work I prioritize:

Deterministic state transitions

Clear data ownership and memory boundaries

Explicit synchronization

Transparency and performance over abstraction

I am particularly interested in building systems from first principles -- understanding why an API  works, not just how it
works.

Overview

behavior.

Technical Highlights

A Planet-Defense style game built on a custom, service driven C++ game engine.

Overview
Asteroid Defense is a real-time C++ game built on a custom engine. The project
explores service driven architecture, call order clarity, and entity systems.

Technical Overview

Service driven architecture with dual engine and game layers, clearly
separating engine and game concerns

Priority based call order control, allowing concise, configurable system
execution order

Entity management system that safely pools objects for efficient game
execution

Lightweight entity overlap detection designed for scenes with hundreds of
moving entities

Technologies
C++17, SFML

Timeless 2D is a lightweight game engine written in Python and PyGame.
Timeless2D explores various aspects of real-time game engines, such as
